Name: JHS 383 PHILLIPPA SCHUYLER
overview: Students at our school are assigned instructional programs that meet their individual gifts and talents. Philippa Schuyler offers a variety of acceleration and enrichment opportunities that include advanced language arts and math classes, Regents classes in algebra, living environment, earth science, French, and Spanish. Major performing arts courses are offered in a variety of dance styles including: jazz, modern, ballet, and urban dance. Additional major performing arts courses include: theater, steel pan, and chorus. Major visual arts courses and other electives include: medical studies, technology, robotics, hydroponic gardening, and African American studies. In addition, we offer preparation courses for Specialized High School testing. Our school also offers a state-of-the-art hydroponic science lab. Our instructional program focuses on project-based instruction and assessment to promote rigorous critical-thinking and citizenship skills.

Name: PS 089 CYPRESS HILLS
overview: Cypress Hills Community School (CHCS) is a small, community-based, dual-language school where students learn in Spanish and English. The school's mission is for all students to become fully bilingual and bi-cultural, and to be deeply concerned about themselves and each other, their community, and the world. We offer native language instruction to all students, including: Spanish language arts, content area instruction in Spanish, and targeted tutoring groups during the school day and after school. The small environment allows students to develop positive relationships with their teachers, where they benefit from both academic and emotional support. CHCS has developed a philosophy guided by Project CARE (Communication, Accountability, Respect, and Effort). These core values provide a common language we believe is necessary for fostering and maintaining a peaceful and productive environment.

Name: I S 171 ABRAHAM LINCOLN
overview: Welcome to I.S. 171, Home of the Lincoln Scholar. We at Abraham Lincoln Intermediate School 171 are a community of educators dedicated to the belief that every child can learn and is entitled to a high-quality education. Our students have the opportunity to take the Algebra and US History Regents courses as well the Spanish Language Proficiency exam. We were the first in the city to host the Middle School Student Success Center (MSSSC), which focuses on supporting students' high school and college choice and preparation. Students can choose from visual arts, debate, theater arts, Spanish, coding, and physical education electives. We offer the following after-school programs: Theater/Drama, Video Game Truck, Modeling & Etiquette, and Debate Team. Students can also participate in Student Government, Project BOOST, STEM Club, Student Dances, College Prep assemblies, and MSSSC year-long activities. We also host Family Honor Roll dinners, Student of the Month assemblies, family movie nights, staff vs. student basketball games, and our annual Community Carnival.

Name: JHS 218 JAMES P SINNOTT
overview: James P. Sinnott has a magnet program focused on health and health professions. There is also a wellness committee which focuses on a month-by-month health theme that is ingrained in the culture of the school. We offer students an Honors program with Regents courses, Spanish Dual Language Cohort, and a Dance Cohort. We also have the only Day NYPD/FDNY Explorer Program with the Learning for Life advisory curriculum. All students are exposed to restorative circles in advisory. As participants in New York City's iTeach/iLearn program, students receive a laptop computer for daily use in each class and all classrooms are outfitted with SMART Boards. Parents are always invited to our school to help build culture and to celebrate our students. We provide our students with a stable, secure, and structured learning environment and the highest quality classroom instruction. A wide variety of support and intervention services are also offered. We strive to achieve academic excellence.

Name: JHS 292 MARGARET S DOUGLAS
overview: The mission of J.H.S. 292 is to create a secure environment that embraces each student's individual talents and maximizes his or her potential. Our programs assist in preparing students for higher education while developing their sense of responsibility and building self-esteem. In our quest to produce successful young adults, we have created an open-door policy where teachers, parents, and students work side by side on academics and life experiences to further the growth of students. This is done by the implementation and sustenance of mentoring groups and Student Council, all of which focus on fostering leadership potential, community service, and helping students gain the world view that they need. Parents are impressed by the fact that we offer a performing arts component where each child has the opportunity to participate in an elective that will complement their academics, making them well-rounded citizens.

Name: I S 364 GATEWAY
overview: Our FALCONS enjoy the personalized attention that they receive in our small, nurturing learning academies. Our small academies afford us the opportunity to provide a nurturing environment, where students are able to create lasting relationships with the staff. We strive to cultivate a dynamic environment of advanced thinkers, high achievers, and model citizens. The staff works to develop an educational program based on the unique needs of each student. In collaboration with parents, we support the intellectual, emotional, and social growth of students. We strive for academic excellence by maintaining high expectations. We believe that every child can and will succeed academically and will be able to develop a strong personal sense of discipline and social responsibility. Gateway FALCONS are provided with a rich academic curriculum which is enhanced through the use of SMART Boards and mobile computer labs and differentiated based on student need. Our open-door policy ensures that parents will have full access to their child and parents are able to continuously check their child's progress through the use of our computer grading system. Gateway FALCONS have been accepted into TEAK, Prep for Prep, and A Better Chance programs.

overview: Our focus on academic success and curricular programming is paramount. We are a small school and offer classes of approximately 25 students which allows our students to develop academically and socially. Our teaching staff is extremely caring and focused, and students have multiple opportunities to work through their academic challenges with effective guidance and support. Our staff is very accessible and professional. We are particularly encouraging and open to families, as evident in the number of siblings who attend both the middle and high school sections. We have a full-size pool, state-of-the-art computer room, and a new media center.

Name: JHS 051 WILLIAM ALEXANDER
overview: Students enjoy an inclusive, engaging and rigorous academic environment, as well as many educational field trips. We offer accelerated courses in each subject, including seventh grade accelerated math and the Living Environment Science and Algebra Regents in eighth grade. Our program also includes three years of a second language (French or Spanish) and a three-year, in-depth study of drama, instrumental music, dance, chorus, art or photography. Our social/emotional support and academic and artistic enrichment programs help prepare students for the best high schools in NYC. Over 85% of our eighth graders receive an offer to their top choices. Parents have a voice via the School Leadership Team, Parent Association, fundraising, and volunteerism. Our non-captive lunch/recess allows students to explore the campus and community. We believe that outdoor play is essential to recharging the mind and fostering independence, social skills, and responsible behaviors. We are recipients of the 2012 Golden Apple Award, 2014 Respect for All Award, and have been a top NYC Fundraising School for Pennies for Patients since 2002. We also offer travel opportunities, including trips abroad and grade-wide overnight trips.

Name: NEW HORIZONS SCHOOL
overview: Carroll Gardens School for Innovation (CGSI) is an award-winning school that has been recognized city-wide and nationally. CGSI is an Apple Distinguished School for 2016-2018. This designation is reserved for programs that meet the criteria for innovation, leadership, and educational excellence. This partnership with Apple provides our students with blended learning opportunities and individual schedules within an asynchronous model. CGSI is one of Chancellor Farina's showcase schools, highlighted for "Supporting All Students Through Collaboration." We are also part of Mastery Collaborative second cohort. Mastery Collaborative is an intensive professional development program designed for NYC public middle and high schools use of technology and student-centered learning to improve student college- and career-readiness. Responsive mentoring between staff and students helps to maintain each student's academic and social-emotional growth as well as strengthen the home-school connection.

Name: BROOKLYN SECONDARY SCHOOL FOR COLLABORATIVE STUD
overview: Brooklyn Collaborative is a member of the national network of Expeditionary Learning Schools (ELS), which promotes rigorous and engaging curriculum; active, inquiry-based pedagogy; and a school culture that demands and teaches compassion and good citizenship. The ELS approach is experiential and project-based. Teachers lead students in learning expeditions that engage them in original research to create high-quality products. ELS learning encourages students to go beyond the classroom. Brooklyn Collaborative's mission is to be a diverse and respectful Expeditionary Learning School, committed to developing students and staff who are kind, open-minded, persistent, responsible, and courageous. With support from peers, staff, families, and school partners, students engage in challenging academic and social experiences that prepare them for college-level learning and full participation in civic life. Students learn to apply their intellect and effort to benefit themselves and their community.

Name: SECONDARY SCHOOL FOR RESEARCH
overview: At Park Slope Collegiate, we are committed to creating and maintaining a diverse and integrated student body and faculty. We believe that students learn best in a heterogeneous environment where they can compare what they know and think with the knowledge and ideas of adult scholars as well as with the knowledge and ideas of their classmates. Our very small middle school offers students the opportunity to grow and learn with classmates from diverse backgrounds within an engaging setting. Teachers accustomed to heterogeneous classrooms provide students a variety of individual and group learning experiences. Once a week, students meet in circles to strengthen the community of the classroom by learning more about each other, practicing active listening skills, playing group games, and exploring their social and emotional interests. As a 6-12 school, we also guarantee a seat in our high school for any middle school student interested in continuing at Park Slope Collegiate.

Name: SCHOOL FOR INTERNATIONAL STUDIES
printedschoolname: Boerum Hill School for International Studies
overview: The Boerum Hill School for International Studies is an International Baccalaureate French Language Public School that serves 600 students in grades 6-12. With the implementation of the International Baccalaureate philosophy and mission, we aim to support learning for all students that is both challenging and relevant to real life. We offer a rigorous and engaging curriculum that enables students to understand and manage the complexities of the world and provide them with the skills for taking responsible action for the future. Students are enrolled in French Immersion courses and are encouraged to participate in our early bird and/or after-school program (which includes: theater, soccer, debate, chess, basketball, table-tennis, coding, and dance). Students receive a comprehensive liberal arts education grounded in inquiry and project-based learning, while participating in numerous educational trips and excursions. Middle school students will take the Algebra, Living Environment, and US History regents in the eighth grade. With parent consent, students have the option of going off campus for lunch. Parental involvement through our Leadership Team, the PTA, volunteer work, and fundraising efforts foster a successful school community.

Name: JHS 088 PETER ROUGET
printedschoolname: The Park Slope Educational Complex at (M.S. 88)
overview: Middle School 88 provides students with a dynamic learning environment centered around project-based, student-directed, and personalized learning platforms. Our partnerships with Poly/NYU and Columbia University support critical thinking through STEM instruction for teachers and students. As partners with the Gates Foundation and Facebook, we have greater resources to deepen and enrich our practices. We are a comprehensive school divided into three thematic and diverse learning communities. Throughout the year, we celebrate integrated project work where students present solutions to real world problems. Blended learning and innovation within an integrated curriculum, align to initiatives such as Samsung Solve for Tomorrow and LEGO robotics. In addition to our rigorous academic program, we support social-emotional learning and the development of Core Values. Our free after-school enrichment offers something for everyone with art, music, dance, sports, and technology. Our school community includes and supports gifted and talented programs, special education services, ELL instruction, dual language, physical education, and a wide range of after-school offerings making M.S. 88 an exciting place to learn and grow.

Name: IS 136 CHARLES O DEWEY
overview: Charles O. Dewey Middle School staff inspire young minds today to create leaders for tomorrow. The school community provides students with a foundation to become strong leaders. Dewey adopted the Leader in Me program to encourage students to be leaders and goal-setters in their personal and public lives. Each week, students have their normal core curriculum focusing on Common Core instruction with technology and career-readiness infused in all lessons, along with a period devoted to lessons on the Seven Habits. There are a variety of opportunities for creativity through the arts in the classrooms. We offer fine arts, digital photography, a choral music program, web-design, spoken word, Latin dance, robotics, and our own art gallery. We specialize in limitless opportunities through project-based learning using STREAM (science, technology, reading, engineering, art, and mathematics). All classrooms have wireless internet access with laptops for each student, Elmos, and SMART Boards.

Name: NEW VOICES S. OF ACAD. & CREAT
printedschoolname: New Voices School of Academic & Creative Arts
overview: New Voices School of Academic & Creative Arts (M.S. 443) was established as a small middle school to provide students with an academically rigorous education coupled with a creative, artistic program that enables them to be successful in their personal and academic life. With the support of strong parent involvement, community partnerships, and a diverse community, we have created an environment that nurtures students, both artistically and academically. New Voices has staff who are committed to teaching and learning through a teacher-driven professional development program. Teachers are committed to developing the talent and knowledge of our students and ignite their artistic passions. We believe that children who study and practice the arts enhance their intellect, learn self-discipline, and realize the global implications of creativity and culture. We aim to allow our students to excel in a positive, collaborative environment.

Name: SUNSET PARK PREP
overview: Sunset Park Prep is a caring community school dedicated to helping individual students grow through interactive learning and a broad range of experiences designed to create well-rounded students. Prep aims to ignite intellectual curiosity and to prepare all students for high school and beyond, with particular attention paid to the social-emotional needs of adolescents. In addition to a rigorous curriculum, Prep also provides a variety of enrichment opportunities, from after-school clubs to exciting trips and experiential learning opportunities. Parents appreciate that students, staff, and families support each other to ensure an atmosphere where educational excellence flourishes. The principal's open door policy welcomes parents to speak with her; the bilingual parent coordinator works closely with parents; and teachers are available through PupilPath (Prep's online grade book), phone, and email. Student/Teacher planned events, from Global Awareness Week and Community Week to Family Science, Reading, and Math Nights, celebrate our tight-knit school community.

Name: PS 138 BROOKLYN
overview: P.S. 138 truly believes that all students can learn if they are taught properly. With this motto in mind, P.S. 138's students are constantly being exposed to a variety of academic subjects. Our instructional strategies challenge and benefit all of our pupils. We offer an accelerated program designed to promote students’ intellectual capacity in all subject areas. Accelerated students are instructed two to three grades above level. They are also involved in positive social activities after school, at school, and in the community. P.S. 138 works collaboratively with local colleges in order to promote student learning by preparing students academically and socially. P.S. 138 works with community organizations before, during, and after school to provide students with many opportunities to excel in their respective subjects. Parents, teachers, and the entire community work collaboratively for the benefit of all of our pupils.

They also love our clubs and student government, which provide multiple opportunities for them to express their views and build school spirit through a variety of special events. Our school is a hub of daytime, after-school, and weekend activities that combine to create an intimate and child-centered environment that challenges students academically, while allowing them to explore their talents and interests. With fewer than 300 students enrolled each year, we are able to improve academic achievement for our students by personalizing the learning process for each child.

Name: THE SCHOOL OF INTEGRATED LEARNING
overview: As a college- and career-bound school, we have high expectations for all scholars, accompanied by high levels of support. As an Extended Learning Time (ELT) school, our curriculum emphasizes Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) in settings where scholars are challenged to use critical thinking skills, connecting their learning to the real world. In order to allow all of our eighth-grade scholars to sit the Living Environment Regent, they take the eighth-grade NYS Science Test in seventh grade. Scholars in our Integrated Learning Academy K354A are also on pace to graduate with Integrated Algebra and US History Regents. We offer art, theater, music, and dance as classroom subjects. A vast majority of our scholars get accepted to their first choice high school, with a number of them attending specialized high schools each year. All classrooms have SMART Boards, along with state-of-the-art technology and science labs, a mobile science lab, and laptop carts. Our scholars set personal goals regarding their learning, with academic intervention services offered to provide the necessary support to meet the Common Core Learning Standards. Parents are kept informed via auto-dials, email, and text updates, a monthly newsletter, and our school website.

overview: Parkside Preparatory Academy is an institution that values learning for everyone in the community—parents, students, and staff. The wealth of resources available to all allows each learner to excel and to engage in diverse learning experiences. From academics and sports to learning how to cook and exploring career options, our school provides it all. We are a multicultural haven that embraces diversity and promotes respect for all. Our school program builds a strong foundation in preparing students for life, college, and career. A number of school committees and affiliates support our students. Our school is safe, nurturing, personalized, and embraces core values of commitment, honesty, hard work, respect, collaboration, and excellence for all. Parkside Prep provides a private education in a public setting.

Name: EBBETTS FIELD MIDDLE SCHOOL
overview: Ebbets Field Middle School is an international education center, founded in 2005. Ninety percent of our students are immigrants or children of immigrants. We are proud of this heritage and diversity. Our instructional week is five hours longer than similar schools ensuring all students meet and exceed the challenges of the Common Core and city-wide instructional shifts. We are one of four Turnaround Arts schools in NYC. Turnaround is a presidential initiative for academic success through the arts. Marc Anthony is our celebrity partner and is committed to our school’s success. All of our curricula, from mathematics to social studies, are infused with the arts. To ensure that our students are college and career ready, every student is given an iPad to experience the curriculum through an interactive, hands-on, minds-on format. We have partnerships that extend learning and guarantee the educational, physical, social, and emotional development of each of our students and families.

Name: JHS 201 THE DYKER HEIGHTS
overview: The Goal of Dyker Heights Middle School is clear: "Academic Excellence Is the Key To Success." We provide a rigorous and nurturing environment that meets the needs of our diverse student population. We encourage our students to work hard, explore new interests, develop positive relationships, and build on existing strengths. Dyker offers a variety of programs and resources during and after school to enrich each child's overall development. We continue to focus on parent involvement. This is achieved through the use of the school website, emails, school messenger, PupilPath, parent engagement activities, and the PTA. Dyker Heights Intermediate School strives to prepare your child to be college- and career-ready, but ultimately, give your child the foundation to be successful in all of their future endeavors.

Name: JHS 259 WILLIAM MCKINLEY
overview: McKinley offers something for everyone: rigorous academics, arts, and sports. We offer gifted and honors programs. McKinley has been an A-rated school for many years. Parents are always welcomed at McKinley. Our Parent Teacher Association (PTA) meetings are themed and actively involve parents and their children. Information is always made public through Pupil Path, our website, emails, and telephone. Interpreters are always available. We offer laptops, Interactive Boards, and wireless internet. Our mural has been featured on ABC, CBS, Channel 25, and The New York Times. We offer two state of the art science labs and all students receive hands-on science activities. We feature a new business course called Virtual Enterprises Junior Ventures. In this course, students create their own product and market it for sale (similar to Shark Tank). We also offer an Independent Investigation Method (IIM) class where students focus on learning research skills through project based activities. Attending McKinley is an experience, not just a school with classes.

Name: JHS 227 EDWARD B SHALLOW
overview: Our school consists of three grade academies. Each academy focuses on the Common Core initiatives in order to support the developmental and academic needs of every student. Each grade is supervised by a separate team comprised of teachers, a dean, a guidance counselor, and an assistant principal. The mission of the school calls for unity and states: "Together building a better tomorrow today." Each class belongs to a graduate-year cohort which serves as their primary goal at Shallow. Our instructional bottom lines are as follows: academic intervention, using data to drive instruction, implementing collaborative learning environments, language development, and multiple entry points to increase student understanding and achievement.

Name: PS 229 DYKER
overview: The motto of P.S./I.S. 229 is "Home, School, Community." Families appreciate our small school community in which students receive individual attention, including academic and social/emotional support throughout the year. Students like the variety of activities, the service projects, as well as the willingness of the staff to support academic success. Our middle school grades meet in a newly constructed building addition which opened in September 2009. It includes a state-of-the-art science lab, art and music rooms, a new library, cafeteria, classrooms, and a 5,400-square-foot gymnasium. We are proud that 100% of our Honors Academy students have passed their accelerated science and math courses, including the accompanying NYS Regents Examinations.

Name: IS 096 SETH LOW
overview: At Seth Low I.S. 96, our mission is to create an environment that fosters responsible students who take ownership of their academic achievements. Our academics integrate music, graphic arts, and international studies through core courses in math, science, social studies, and ELA. The Common Core Learning Standards come to life as students participate in debates, conduct laboratory experiments, and publish articles for our school newspaper. Technology is infused in all classrooms through the use of interactive SMART Boards, laptops, iPads, Chromebooks, and computer-based programs. Communication with our parents is successfully done through our online grading system, PupilPath. Our Lion's Den Service Learning program develops projects that help support the school, local, and world community. Our Honors program gives students the opportunity to gain high school Regents credits in all core courses making them competitive for specialized high school placement.

Name: IS 228 DAVID A BOODY
overview: I.S. 228 offers a creative environment that brings out students' talents in safe, encouraging, and challenging ways. We have zero tolerance for bullying and have partnered up with Bridg-it. We also have a Student Teacher Outreach Mentorship Program, where our teachers give up their time to have lunch with small groups of students. Our paramount goal is to empower all students with the necessary skills to become college- and career-ready. All members of our school community will be responsible for creating a nurturing environment that supports rigorous learning delivered through a high-quality curriculum aligned to the Common Core. We strive to implement engaging and rigorous lessons that meet the needs of all students. Parents are respected partners and are supported by the district's first Parent Engagement Center. Parents are in constant communication through innovative apps such as Pupil Path and Remind. I.S. 228 offers free night classes that teach English as a New Language to the parents of new immigrant students and other interested adults. We run two full after-school programs from 2:30pm-5:30pm, five days a week with a variety of academic and recreational activities.

Name: IS 281 JOSEPH B CAVALLARO
overview: It is our vision to help guide students in the development of their character and academic potential so they can become teachers, leaders, and dreamers. We provide rigorous, challenging, and content-rich programs to prepare students for college and careers. Staff, parents, and students effectively communicate, collaborate, and support our high academic and behavioral standards. We have a dedicated PTA and use PupilPath, the One Call Now telephone messaging system, the REMIND text app, and our school website to work together as one towards the complete education of every child. I.S. 281 is a technology-rich school with an emphasis on STEM education, as well as a developed arts program incorporated within the school day. We offer free day and evening courses teaching English to our parents and other adults in the community.

Name: BROOKLYN STUDIO SECONDARY SCHOOL
overview: At Brooklyn Studio Secondary School, the needs of all learners are addressed in a fully inclusive setting which encourages each student to be an active participant in setting, monitoring, and meeting challenging academic goals. Curriculum is aligned to the Common Core learning standards and is enhanced through the most current technologies and web programs. Our small setting allows students to feel secure and supported in their relationships with their teachers. Parents appreciate the small size of our school and the supportive environment that it provides their children. Our students are exposed to a variety of arts experiences throughout the day, and continue their studies in instrumental music, digital communication in our high school. Another important factor for parents is that students from our middle school are given priority to attend our high school.

Name: JHS 062 THE DITMAS
overview: To help prepare our students for the ever-changing world of technology, most of our classrooms have SMART Boards. There are also three computer labs and several mobile labs totaling more than 550 desktops/laptops and 90 iPads. Additionally, our library has 30 iPads for student use. Ditmas participates in the Software Engineering Program where our students study computer programming, web design, scratch, circuitry, and robotics. Our Law and Community Service Institute features a community service program where our students go to various schools to perform community service during the school day. Our Academic, Performing and Visual Arts Institute features an intensive arts program of dance, chorus, keyboard, band, and visual arts. Our school has partnerships with Power My Learning, Groundswell, and New York Cares.

overview: P.S. 99, located in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, is a pre-kindergarten to eighth-grade school which serves a population of students from culturally diverse backgrounds. We are a collaborative school community dedicated to achieving high standards of academic excellence for all of our students. Through high quality standard-driven instruction, a nurturing environment, and the development of civic, social, and technological skills necessary to function productively in the world community, we create a community of lifelong learners. We have a new computer lab that utilizes the latest technology available to us and have access to SMART Board technology.

Name: PS 121 NELSON A ROCKEFELLER
printedschoolname: Nelson A. Rockefeller (P.S./I.S. 121) Magnet School of Applied Life Sciences
overview: It is the vision of P.S./I.S. 121 Nelson A. Rockefeller Magnet School of Applied Life Sciences to sustain a learning environment that brings experiences with the living environment directly to students in an urban setting, resulting in increased student knowledge and skills that can be applied to improving their lives, their community, and their world. They will develop self-efficacy, a genuine kindness towards the environment and humanity, and become a community of lifelong learners. Our students will be productive leaders of society. It is the mission of P.S./I.S. 121 Nelson A. Rockefeller Magnet School of Applied Life Sciences to create and sustain a learning environment centered on a Life Sciences curriculum. We will expose students to various living environments in order to provide regular hands-on and minds-on experiential learning. In this learning environment, students will regularly access critical-thinking processes by engaging in the scientific method in order to achieve high standards of academic excellence. Students will work collaboratively to solve problems and apply what they learn to improve their world. Together we make a difference!

We provide a positive learning environment for all students and offer various engaging classes and extracurricular activities for students to participate in, including Shorefront Y After-School Program, STEM activities, and Debate Club.

Name: IS 239 MARK TWAIN
printedschoolname: Mark Twain for the Gifted & Talented (I.S. 239)
overview: Students thrive in a community that blends academic rigor with visual and performing arts. Every student has a focus in one of our Talent programs: Art, Computer Science STEM, Creative Writing/Journalism, Dance, Drama, Instrumental Music (Strings or Winds), Media, Science, and Vocal Music. Parents appreciate the personalized attention of our mini-school cluster system. Teachers and support staff have time in their weekly schedule to collaborate with parents and caregivers to provide the best academic and social/emotional development for each student. Almost all graduates go on to NYC's Specialized High Schools and select programs. All students receive and utilize iPads and interactive digital curriculum throughout their courses.

Name: PS 288 THE SHIRLEY TANYHILL
overview: We take pride at P.S./I.S. 288 in providing each of our scholars with a quality and well-rounded education on a daily basis. We offer our middle school scholars a rigorous academic curriculum. Which includes rich opportunities to engage in text-based discussions, evidenced-based writing, high level mathematical concepts, computer technology, scientific inquiry, etc. We are also pioneering the Billion Oyster project in Coney Island through our partnership with Urban Advantage. At 288 our scholars also have the opportunity to engage in performing arts, leadership, sports, and other curricular activities. Our Performing Arts department offers our scholars dance, vocal, and fine art opportunities. Our Leadership curriculum provides our scholars the opportunity to lead by doing. 288 Athletics offers our scholars competitive opportunities in track and field (nationally-ranked track program) as well as boys and girls basketball. We offer intramural activities in flag football, soccer, and developmental basketball. We add new programs yearly. Our middle school Green Team handles all of our urban gardening, our 288 News Team provide opportunity in broadcasting, and our 288 Senate middle school members help govern and lead our school.

Name: IS 303 HERBERT S. EISENBERG
printedschoolname: Herbert S. Eisenberg (I.S. 303) Academy for Career Exploration
overview: The Herbert S Eisenberg Middle School for Career Exploration believes in "Children First, High Expectations, NO Excuses." Our school exists to benefit our entire student population, and thereby the members of our community. The staff and parents of our school are committed to providing the best possible education to all of our students by meeting their individual needs so that they can succeed to the best of their abilities. We are committed to helping our students to fully develop their skills and talents and use them to contribute to their communities, city, state, and the world at large. Our students go on to make us proud and we are committed to seeing that such successes continue. It is our firm belief, that all students can reach their full academic and social potential with the support of our school and families working as one cohesive unit.

Name: SCI TECHNOLOGY AND RESEARCH EARLY COLLEGE HIGH
printedschoolname: Science, Technology and Research Early College School at Erasmus
overview: Science, Technology, and Research (STAR) Early College School at Erasmus is a small screened sixth- through twelfth-grade Early College school. Students entering our middle school are placed into one of four houses where they will compete with their peers—academically and athletically—throughout their educational journey, and become part of all aspects of our school community. Our dynamic team of teachers and Brooklyn College professors are eager to prepare students interested in science, mathematics, and technology for college and the working world. With our partners, we offer a range of challenging academic courses that give students firsthand exposure to the demands of high school and college by using field-based and hands-on methods of instruction. Students will use the rich resources on the Brooklyn College and other City University of New York (CUNY) campuses as their learning laboratories. In addition to their high school diploma, our high school students may earn up to 61 college credits, tuition free, from Brooklyn College enabling many of them to begin college as a sophomore or junior at a CUNY, SUNY, or private university.

The House System: Upon entry into STAR all students are entered into a house. Throughout the year, houses compete in both academic and extracurricular activities. Each house is awarded points according to how well they compete. At the end of the year the members of the winning house are awarded a grand trophy as well as an end-of-the-year prize.

Name: ANDRIES HUDDE
overview: Andries Hudde, I.S. 240 STEM Magnet School, promotes choice, equity, diversity, and excellence for all students. Students have full access to cutting edge, state of the art technology, preparing them for 21st century STEM based careers. Our students make real world connections through instruction. We create, collaborate, character build, and foster good self-esteem. We educate the whole child. We believe our instruction builds community, perks student curiosity, and bridges gaps. Our mission is to empower our students by providing solid academic skills, supporting them with resources that will make for dynamic future leaders and entrepreneurs. Our goal is to maximize student growth by providing them with a well-rounded, interdisciplinary education through project-based learning. Students will experience hands-on innovation, making for critical and creative thinkers. Students love to be at Hudde because of the many after-school and Saturday activities. We are rigorous, safe, and nurturing. We value the uniqueness of each student, preparing them for academic, artistic, musical, physical, and social/emotional growth. Hudde is more than a school, we are a family that is "Magnificent in Midwood".

Name: I. S. 381
overview: I.S. 381 offers an intimate and nurturing environment for students, as well as one in which academic rigor and excellence is valued. Our staff works collaboratively to develop enriched, rigorous, and individualized curricula designed to meet the learning and social developmental needs of students. I.S. 381 offers both accelerated and schoolwide enrichment courses that promote students' interests and abilities. Through the use of iZone technology the school offers high school curricula in Algebra and Living Environment Regents. The school also offers Specialized High Schools Test preparation. Additionally, every child has the opportunity to participate in Latin as a foreign language, visual arts, and schoolwide enrichment clusters. The Schoolwide Enrichment Model is a research-based model designed to provide students with opportunities to engage in a wide range of experiences that will enhance creativity and passion. Enrichment clusters include: photography, drama, movie making, visual art, LEGO robotics, dance, designing games/coding, track and field, and blogging. The school also has a partnership with a community-based organization, Sports and Arts in School Foundations, that offers an after-school program.

Name: PS 095 THE GRAVESEND
overview: P.S./I.S. 95 is a culturally diverse school in the heart of Gravesend, Brooklyn. Our mission is to provide a safe and nurturing environment where every student is encouraged to be a lifelong learner. All students are exposed to an integrated curriculum which focuses on academics as well as social needs. Students are offered a variety of courses in core subject areas, as well as the arts (visual arts, chorus, instrumental music, and dance) and our innovative STEM program providing all middle school students with engineering, coding, and robotics courses. Students in grades six through eight have the experience of middle school in a smaller environment where all staff knows each individual child.

Critical focus is on the STEM curriculum, with secondary integration of a liberal arts curriculum also tied to the school concentration in health and wellness. Our students have a tremendous advantage in their continuing education toward college- and career-readiness through partnerships with universities, media outlets, restaurants, manufacturers, urban farms, caterers, chefs, authors, and more.

Name: JHS 014 SHELL BANK
overview: Our school provides a well-planned transition program to help parents and students acclimate to the new requirements of middle school. Students at Shell Bank enjoy getting to know their teachers in small group settings. Our grade structure allows teachers, administrators, and guidance counselors to get to know students on an individual basis. Individual support is given to students and parents during their transitions through middle school. Shell Bank maintains unique programs that focus on college- and career-readiness, as well as an ongoing collaborative support system with parents. Students enjoy a selection of courses that incorporate project-based learning and student interest. Our school also has a partnership with North Shore Animal League in a unique program called Mutt-I-grees where students work with therapy and shelter dogs. Our staff focuses on character development and civic responsibility, offering experiences that are intellectually and physically challenging. Our school also has the only Specialized Program for the Intellectually Disabled in District 22, which is staffed by teachers with special training and experience in this area.

Name: PS 206 JOSEPH F LAMB
overview: P.S./I.S. 206 is a multi-cultural school with approximately 1,500 students, 360 of which are in our middle school. Students have the opportunity for engaging discussions centered on critical thinking. Staff and administrators know students by their names and support their individual needs. Parents often want their child to attend our school because they feel confident that their child is in a safe and highly rigorous school. Students enjoy a healthy balance of strong academic instruction along with opportunities to develop their strengths in technology and the arts. Community service is a staple of our school and students enjoy the rewards of helping others. One of the most coveted positions is that of a student mentor where middle school students are able to support elementary students both academically and socially. SMART Boards, digital projectors, iPads, personal Androids, and over 200 new wireless laptops ensure that our students are ready for the technology-driven future.

Name: JHS 234 ARTHUR W CUNNINGHAM
overview: Cunningham is a family-oriented, safe, and nurturing school whose students come from more than 30 different countries. In an effort to prepare our student body for college and career, we empower them to think critically and engage in rich peer-to-peer collaboration across all disciplines. Cunningham focuses on science, engineering, technology, math, sustainability, and environmental issues through hands-on STEM related activities, robotics, coding, Ever-fi, residencies, field trips, partnerships, and service-learning opportunities. Students will become communicators and collaborators while learning new and exciting engineering and technology skills, conducting research, applying math concepts, and striving to create a model for a sustainable community. The program heightens students' curiosity in STEM subjects by laying a solid foundation for futures in science, engineering, math, and tech fields through all subject areas by teaching the critical skills that life and work demand.

Name: JHS 278 MARINE PARK
overview: Marine Park J.H.S., located within the beautiful surroundings of Marine Park, provides a nurturing school environment where students develop college- and career-readiness through high level academics, various arts programs, and technology. Tech is infused into all of our classrooms through the use of SMART Boards, laptops, iPads, and e-readers. Students research skills on building and design which they explore through our award-winning STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) programs. Students also discover their talents through our arts programs. Marine Park embraces the comfort of our students in a fully air-conditioned building including all classrooms, the gymnasium, the cafeteria, and the auditorium. Parents and teachers enjoy a close relationship. There are multiple opportunities for correspondence including emails, PupilPath, School Messenger, phone calls, SLT, PA meetings, and parent workshops.

Name: PS 137 RACHEL JEAN MITCHELL
overview: The mission of P.S./I.S. 137 is to create a community of students, parents, and staff joined in the pursuit of excellence through academic achievement and personal growth. We seek to provide a challenging curriculum with flexibility to meet the needs of every student. We want our children to have esteem for themselves and others, and to be knowledgeable and sensitive to their own culture as well as the culture of others. We place a strong emphasis on literacy and personal expression of ideas through speaking and writing. We believe that all students should master basic skills. We stress scientific exploration and application in technology as well as physical and artistic expression. We exhort parents, students, and staff to live and work as a community, focusing on the needs of our children and celebrating their successes.

Name: PS 184 NEWPORT
overview: At P.S./I.S. 184, our motto is: "Where Excellence Is Expected and Greatness Is Created." We uphold and implement our motto on a daily basis with the entire school community. Our goal is to create a community school where parents, staff, students, and the community are collectively responsible for developing the future leaders of our community and world. Our mission is to raise student achievement, improve instructional practices, and optimize school progress by providing all members of the school community with the necessary professional learning to create effective change. In addition to offering after-school support in ELA and math, we partner with the Italian-American Civil Rights League after-school program for homework help, academic enrichment, and extracurricular activities. Additionally, Student Success mentors have been assigned to work with our students on improving their attendance. As a Community Learning School, we have access to a wide array of additional resources to support the entire community.

Name: PS 284 LEW WALLACE
printedschoolname: The Gregory Jocko Jackson School of Sports, Art, and Technology (P.S./I.S. 284)
overview: At the Gregory Jocko Jackson School of Sports, Art, and Technology (GJS), "Where we care about our students, our community, and our future," our goal is to ensure all of our students have the tools and knowledge they need to succeed in school and beyond. As a community school, we provide many resources to our students and families, from an array of Extended Learning Time activities (such as Top Chef cooking, film-making and college- & career-readiness) to monthly family fun nights to specialized test prep. At GJS, we instill the values of trustworthiness, integrity, generosity, empathy, and respect, emphasizing that these values are the key to our students' success. Our GJS Tigers display these values daily, helping each other in the classroom, collaborating on sports teams, joining after-school programs, and participating in community service activities. Each student is individually supported in their social and academic growth by our caring staff and program partners, including Single Shepherd and Partnership With Children. We can't wait for you to join our school community!

Name: PS/IS 323
overview: P.S./I.S. 323 is a pre-K through grade eight school located in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The school’s mission is to facilitate a learning climate which supports the educational needs of all students, including English Language Learners, special education students, and high-achieving students to achieve the academic foundation essential for success in high school, college, and life. Our school motto is: “I am a winner and an achiever! I am gifted, talented, and smart! We are a team of winners because we work hard together!” In addition to offering a challenging curriculum, P.S./I.S. 323 also offers a wonderful arts program. The school building is a modern facility that complements a nurturing environment for our students and provides a positive influence on students’ behavior and academic achievement. Our administrators and staff believe in educating children holistically. We consider ourselves a family and every child in our school has the support of every staff member.

Name: IS 392
overview: Intermediate School 392, located in Brooklyn, is a grade 6-8 middle school with 300 students. Our mission is to establish and maintain a school environment that is challenging and nurturing. We promote high levels of academic achievement utilizing a rigorous, interdisciplinary curriculum focusing on the higher-order thinking skills of application, synthesis, and evaluation. This curriculum infuses the arts, creates articulate public speakers, and encourages students to become productive members of society. The Leadership Program provides mentoring for at-risk male students with successful role models from the community. In order to build school spirit and develop students' personal interests, we offer various after-school programs. Parents are also significant contributors within the school community, working harmoniously with the staff to ensure their children's success. At I.S. 392, we truly live by the mantra of the African proverb: "It takes a whole village to raise a child."

Name: KAPPA V
printedschoolname: KAPPA V (Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy V)
overview: KAPPA V/M.S. 518 is a small, high-performing middle school, serving grades six through eight. KAPPA is modeled after the acclaimed KIPP Academy in the Bronx. We foster a nurturing environment that supports, challenges, and raises the expectations for youth in Brooklyn. KAPPA V has an accelerated learning program with emphasis on rigor, discipline, reading, writing, mathematics, and teamwork. Our character focus is on respect, responsibility, and community service. KAPPA stands for Knowledge and Power Preparatory Academy, and the model stresses high academic expectations in a supportive atmosphere with rewards for high achievement. Parent involvement is also emphasized. Open Houses will be held in October and November. Interviews will be scheduled in December and January. Please contact our parent coordinator, Ms. Juanita Williams, at 718-922-4690 for Open House dates and times.

Name: MOTT HALL IV
overview: Our mission at Mott Hall IV is to develop and nurture academic and social leaders by providing a safe environment, which promotes mutual respect among scholars, teachers, parents, administrators, and the community. Through our curriculum, our scholars will enter high school fully prepared to compete globally, and work towards college- and career-readiness. The academic experience at Mott Hall IV will stimulate students' curiosity and critical thinking in order to create productive citizens and leaders. It is our vision that all stakeholders will work collaboratively to ensure scholars receive a standards-based rigorous academic education that promotes a commitment to leadership and service. The attainment of this vision directly relates to Mott Hall IV's commitment to the school community to provide quality education to all students. It is essential that our students live and embody our core values, which are accountability, leadership, integrity, pride, respect, service, and teamwork.

Name: IS 285 MEYER LEVIN
overview: Our Performing Arts Program provides students with a strong sense of discipline and responsibility. Our teachers take advantage of the natural curiosity, energy, and enthusiasm of sixth through eighth graders. The program supports students at different levels of maturity and includes a balance of teacher-structured and student-initiated activities. The Performing Arts program provides training for beginning and experienced students in dance, drama, instrumental band, steel pan orchestra, and vocal music. The courses represent a selection of introductory classes together with those that fulfill the needs of highly talented young artists. The curriculum focuses on basic skills, a disciplined manner of inquiry, individual creativity, and good study habits. Students are encouraged to work cooperatively and to share their special gifts and talents.

Name: PS 109
overview: Our students receive a quality education in a small nurturing learning environment. It's a place where everybody knows your name. Parents appreciate our small educational community, our emphasis on science and technology, and our desire to equip each and every student with the necessary tools to become a leader of tomorrow. We are part of the iLearnNYC program. iLearnNYC schools are implementing online and blended learning to expand current school boundaries that limit how and when a student can learn. iLearnNYC empowers teachers, administrators, students, and parents with cutting-edge resources, including online content, real-time data on student work, and many more educational tools.

Name: P.S. 66
overview: Our school has established the following goals: increase the number of students who are proficient in ELA and Math, organize classes to reflect the diverse needs of the student body including the Scholars Program, engage in parent orientations at the start of each school year in addition to family engagement opportunities every Tuesday to foster parent relationships, and offer a Specialized High School preparation program. To achieve these goals, we cultivate a safe social-emotional learning environment through the implementation of Restorative Practices. Students enjoy Restorative Circles weekly with their peers. An abundance of after-school opportunities are conducted through a partnership with SASF, Monday through Friday. The Student Council has branded our school as the Blue Jays and our proud basketball and cheerleader teams confidently sport that symbol on their uniforms! The 66 Rock Band and the Middle School Urban/Architect artists work in tandem to keep the arts an integral part of the school experience. Finally, 2017 marks the first year that our school will administer the Living Environment Regents.

Name: IS 068 ISAAC BILDERSEE
overview: I.S. 68 is a school that provides its students with a high-quality education that surrounds Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM). We are a certified Eco-School and are a part of the Billion Oyster Project. Our students learn about science and technology through our pollinating garden and school-wide air purifying initiative. We pride ourselves on our newly implemented robotics program which uses state-of-the-art equipment and 3-D printing. I.S. 68 has a belief system based on Steven Covey's The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People in which students demonstrate positive behavior by being proactive, setting goals, collaborating, and prioritizing. We have a strong focus on student leadership development which is supported by the Leader in Me program. Students also benefit from various partnerships. For example, through our partnership with Long Island University, students have opportunities to visit colleges and universities around the country.

Name: PS 235 LENOX
overview: The Lenox Academy offers an academically accelerated program for middle school students. We provide a high-quality education within a learning environment that supports young learners. Lenox Academy's rigorous academic program, coupled with a highly skilled and experienced staff, has proven successful. Approximately 25 percent of our 8th grade students from the class of 2016 were accepted to specialized high schools. Most have received acceptances to select public high schools, others have accepted placements in private day and boarding schools through scholarships granted by Prep 9. Lenox Academy promotes academic excellence and challenges students to meet NYS standards with distinction. Over 90 percent of our students met standards [Level 3] or met standards with distinction [Level 4] on the 2015-2016 New York State Standardized exams. All of our seniors are administered the English Language Arts Common Core Regents, Living Environment Regents, and Spanish Proficiency exams. A select group of students are administered the Algebra I Regents. Our SONYC after-school program offers expert instruction in martial arts, culinary arts, dance, theater, basketball & volleyball, and photography.

Name: JHS 078 ROY H MANN
printedschoolname: Intermediate School 78: The School of Architectural Design & Innovative Technology
overview: At I.S. 78, The School for Architectural Design and Innovative Technology, our mission is to provide all students with engaging, rigorous, and technology-based learning opportunities which align with the Common Core Learning Standards. All classrooms are air-conditioned and feature a 65-inch LED flat panel SMART Board. Our students enjoy personalized attention from our dedicated grade teams. Every student has access to a full-time academic counselor, a vibrant and diverse arts program, and meaningful after-school activities. Teachers utilize online academic enrichment programs (Achieve3000 & Waggle Math), to collect data that informs instruction, which leads to improved ELA and math skills. Through our Schoolwide Enrichment Model (SEM), students develop skills, foster positive relationships, and experience social growth. Our enrichment clusters, as well as our embedded organizational skills program, promote creativity and collaboration, in support of college- and career- readiness and community service. In partnership with staff, families, and the community, we foster the emotional, social, and intellectual growth of our students, in order to prepare them to reach their full academic potential and become outstanding citizens.

Name: PS 122 MAMIE FAY
overview: Our Academy for the Intellectually Gifted at P.S. 122 is a district-wide Gifted and Talented program with a rich history. Our program design aims to maximize the degree of academic acceleration while providing a diverse array of enrichment opportunities and an emphasis on the physical, social, and emotional well-being of the exceptional students who are admitted to our school. We are committed to the goal of creating lifelong learners by providing a stimulating academic environment centered on students' interests. Academic content work incorporates many opportunities to engage in problem-based learning (PBL), challenging and creative projects, and teacher assessments, as well as self or peer assessments. Students are well prepared for academic requirements of New York City's specialized high schools. At "The Academy," we welcome the constructive participation of all stakeholders. We recognize that vibrant home/school/community partnerships increase the chances of maximizing our students' potential.

Name: ALBERT SHANKER SCHOOL FOR VISUAL AND PERFORMING
printedschoolname: Albert Shanker School for Visual and Performing Arts (I.S. 126)
overview: I.S. 126 is committed to providing a safe learning environment where all students are held accountable to reach high levels of academic achievement. We challenge our students with a rigorous curriculum and college-readiness expectations. In addition to Regents classes, we offer preparatory classes for the Specialized High School Admissions Test (SHSAT) and the NYS State exams. I.S. 126 has a partnership with City Year, who assist our students in developing their academic and leadership skills. We enrich our students through arts residencies with our partners. We have a science lab and computer labs that are state-of-the-art. These programs allow us to extend the academic rigor in the classrooms. I.S. 126 believes parents are equal partners in their children's education. We foster an open-door policy, where parents are encouraged to communicate and build successful relationships with school leaders. We offer bus service for eligible sixth graders. We also have arts residencies with Community Word Project and Alvin Ailey.

Name: IS 141 THE STEINWAY
overview: Nestled in the heart of New York City, Steinway Intermediate School serves the multicultural population of Astoria. Our school consists of three academies that provide students with small learning environments, thus fostering a sense of community and closer collaboration between the school and parents. The Jewels Academy houses all sixth-grade students, while the seventh and eighth grade students are equally split between The Albert Einstein Academy and The William Shakespeare Academy. Dedicated to providing rigorous academic instruction, the school offers a strong Honors program, which provides in-depth study and prepares students for Regents exams in Living Environment and Integrated Algebra I, while also promoting the arts and humanities, by offering dance, music, and two art courses. This year 30 students were accepted into NYC's Specialized High Schools. Moreover, 34 additional students were accepted into Townsend Harris, Bard, Frank Sinatra, Beacon, Baccalaureate, Manhattan/Hunter Science High School, High School of Fashion Industries, and Talent Unlimited.

overview: What parents like best about The OWH School: our safe and welcoming environment, our rigorous curricula that prepares students for college and careers, student-led conferences, the dual language and magnet programs, our core values, our open-door policy, frequent communication, small communities to meet the social and emotional needs of all children, Honors and Regents courses, our on-line grade book (PupilPath), Class Dojo, science/STEM research, interdisciplinary projects, awards celebrations, parent workshops, free adult English as a New Language classes, community partnerships, and high expectations for all students and staff members. What students like best about OWH: a feeling of safety, our challenging academic environment, student collaboration and critical thinking, student-led conferences, teachers, student-centered classrooms, updated technology, St. John's Gear Up, lunch clubs, STEM research with Cornell University, CUNY Arts, Brain Power, Sanford Harmony, Town-Hall, College and Career Days, Harlem Magic Masters Basketball, accessibility to staff, Google Docs, small classes, school spirit days, free tutoring, and students feeling exceptionally well-prepared for high school, college, and a career.

Name: ACADEMY FOR NEW AMERICANS
overview: The Academy for New Americans offers newly arrived immigrant students and their families the opportunity to adjust successfully to their new setting. The program offers a specialized curriculum that facilitates the acquisition of the English language through a one-year programmatic option. Our school is committed to providing the following services to our students: a welcoming climate that is conducive to English language acquisition, a specialized curriculum that focuses on English language proficiency, an environment that promotes self-esteem and addresses the needs of early adolescence, an introduction to the New York City school system, an emphasis on becoming familiar with American culture, computer literacy classes, support services such as counseling and tutoring, and a committed, well-trained staff that guides the students through the transition period as they become acclimated to our multicultural society.

Name: IS 125 THOM J MCCANN WOODSIDE
overview: I.S. 125 is a well-developed school that provides instruction to a very diverse population of students from over 60 countries. Though a large school, we provide a safe, welcoming, and nurturing environment through our small learning communities. Students are divided into four houses with a dedicated assistant principal, guidance counselor, and dean. I.S. 125 offers an extensive arts program. Day and evening performances are offered throughout the school year. I.S. 125 has a unique accelerated program which provides the opportunity for gifted students to sit for Regents exams. Students graduate from I.S. 125 fully prepared for high school and, by extension, college and their career. Parents are an integral part of the I.S. 125 community. They are valued members of the School Leadership Team, PTA, and various other committees. We hold evening events, including a multicultural show and dinner. Weekly parent English as a New Language (ENL) and computer courses are offered.

Name: ROBERT F. WAGNER JR.
printedschoolname: Robert F. Wagner, Jr. Secondary School for Arts and Technology
overview: Our school is known for being academic, artistic, and athletic while providing a warm and welcoming community. Our teachers meet weekly to create rich, meaningful curricula. All students have a CORE teacher responsible for monitoring their progress. Our college- and career-readiness curriculum helps our students become competitive candidates for college and prepares them for the rigors of life after high school. Come to a place where people know you well and are dedicated to supporting your future goals. Many of our staff members have been here for more than 10 years and our graduates often come back and visit. Once you are part of the Wagner family, you will always be a part of the Wagner family!

Name: PS 078
printedschoolname: The Robert F. Wagner Jr. School (P.S./I.S. 78)
overview: We focus on providing our students with a challenging and global education while meeting the emotional, creative, and social needs of all students. We focus on critical thinking and problem solving through interactive literacy and math activities, enhanced through an integration of the arts into the core curriculum. Parents are actively involved in their children's education and we share the joys of watching our children grow, learn new skills, and make friends. We implement the Renzulli Schoolwide Enrichment Model (SEM) in all grades and include parent talent, community volunteers, and experts from the community in developing an enrichment curriculum. By addressing the needs of all students, including our students with special needs, English Language Learners, and gifted students, the SEM Model engages all of the children in visual, musical, spatial, and kinesthetic activities through their interests and talents thereby enabling them to enhance their academic potential.

overview: At P.S./I.S. 127 we will work collaboratively to promote the social and emotional growth of all students and cultivate self-motivated lifelong learners who are college and career ready. Our shared vision is to inspire students to pursue their dreams by fostering a safe, trusting, and nurturing environment that will promote academic, social, and emotional growth of all scholars at P.S./I.S. 127Q. Our school offers three different program choices for English Language Learners (ELL). We have a dual language program that starts in kindergarten and continues through middle school. Students entering the dual language program are given a baseline assessment in order for our school to provide the best services to ELLs.

Name: I S 227 LOUIS ARMSTRONG
overview: The Louis Armstrong Middle School (LAMS), opened in 1979 with the mission of bringing together a group of culturally diverse children to help them grow academically, emotionally, physically, and socially. At LAMS, students are provided a personalized, caring, and supportive environment. The staff works to build the childrens' confidence and work ethic in order to develop a sense of pride in their choices, actions, and quality of work. In addition to the core subjects, LAMS offers Accelerated Regents courses, foreign language courses, music courses, art courses, physical and adaptive fitness courses, and technology courses. The school is affiliated with Queens College, Vaughn College, National Middle School Association, and National School Reform Policy. Our school is an original recipient of the U.S. President Award for Excellence, has been recognized four consecutive years as a Reward Status School, and by the NASSP as being, "one of the top 100 most effective middle schools in the U.S."

Name: INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL 230
overview: Intermediate School 230, The School for Civics in the Community, provides activities that engage, challenge, and stimulate students. Parents appreciate that we are a nurturing school, and as a result we are a very popular school. Our sixth-grade academy is housed in our annex which is located directly across the street from the main building. The main building houses our seventh and eighth grades. The small learning community of the annex provides a very important transition for students entering middle school. Intermediate School 230Q has developed a positive reputation based upon our challenging academic curricula, supportive teachers, and safe environment. Each year, a very limited number of seats are available for students residing outside of our geographical zone in Jackson Heights.

Name: I.S. 5  THE WALTER CROWLEY INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL
overview: At I.S. 5, we talk like scholars, write like experts, think like innovators, and live like leaders. Students appreciate that I.S. 5 provides them with a nurturing learning environment which is focused on developing their academic, emotional, and social needs. They also enjoy the smaller learning environments our communities provide as they can readily communicate with administrators and/or teachers as it relates to their growth. I.S. 5 consists of four learning communities commonly referred to as Community of Scholars, Community of Leaders, Community of Innovators, and Community of Leaders. Our school community is currently engaging in opportunities for project-based learning, with hands-on projects that highlight the importance of global citizenship and the legacies of our contributions in the community at large. We are building student socio- emotional growth through the incorporation of Leader in Me, based on the work of Franklin Covey. Teachers utilize Mastery Connect and Skedula to track student progress, drive instruction, and communicate with parents on a daily basis.

Name: IS 061 LEONARDO DA VINCI
overview: Students in our school are fully immersed in differentiated instruction that targets their individual learning needs. Students are able to select up to two talent activities each school year. I.S. 61 has created five academies within the main school that foster a nurturing environment for our students. Each academy is set up with its own dean, guidance counselor, assistant principal, and staff of teachers, therefore creating a small learning community. Parents are also able to track their child’s progress for each unit through a special Engrade account. To support our efforts to assist students in meeting the standards for college- and career-readiness, parents have an option to select our AGP program for their child. Students are expected to maintain an 85 GPA as well as take all Regents offered by the school. Programs are also available for parents of our school community, including English as a New Language (ENL), GED, and fitness programs.

Name: I.S. 73  THE FRANK SANSIVIERI INTERMEDIATE SCHO
overview: We are a diverse school community that is divided into five small learning communities called academies. Each of these academies serves as a smaller school within our building to help create and foster a nurturing environment for the students they house. We have done this by assigning each academy its own assistant principal, dean, guidance counselor, and staff of teachers. Each academy is geographically located in a specific area of the building and has its own lunch and assembly periods. In order to provide students with an opportunity to become active members of the school community, I.S. 73's Student Council has been established to enhance school spirit and to improve the overall student experience. These students are elected to one-year positions and serve as representatives of their grade level as well as their homeroom class. Student Council members are responsible for discussing school-wide concerns and activities during the year. In addition, our school provides all eighth graders the opportunity to take the Specialized High School Exam in school during the school day at I.S. 73. Kaplan provides free test prep prior to the exam for all of our students who choose to sit for the exam.

Name: IS 077
overview: I.S. 77 is a family of learners. We offer programs for special progress and honors, English as a New Language, and special education. We offer Spanish, with differentiation for native speakers. Each classroom is equipped with a laptop, a projector with a document camera, and speakers. There are opportunities for students to become involved in community outreach programs. We celebrate a Student of the Month based on virtues. We have a partnership with the Greater Ridgewood Youth Council who sponsors an after-school program which offers homework help, sports, and recreation in our school. We also work with the Youth Council in their young adult internship program which benefits many of our graduates. Our PTA is very active and encourages all parents to be a part of our family of learners. Through the use of the internet program PupilPath, parents and teachers are able to communicate with each other regarding grades and assignments.

Name: IS 093 RIDGEWOOD
overview: In carrying out our mission to prepare all of our students for the rigors of high school, college, and 21st century careers, we offer our students opportunities to take selected Regents exams. Our curriculum and instruction in all major subject areas are aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards. Our Spanish Dual Language program and our STEM program are available to incoming students (includes LEGO Robotics, Coding, and our partnership with Urban Advantage, a premier NYC science organization). Additionally, we offer our students a wide variety of activities in the areas of sports, art, music, drama, and community service in partnership with the Greater Ridgewood Youth Council Beacon Program. We offer leadership programs such as Peer Mediation, Beautiful Me, and Unleashed.

Name: JHS 157 STEPHEN A HALSEY
overview: Students enjoy being part of a school that provides a nurturing environment which celebrates their work and achievement and offers a variety of enrichment activities. Students in our accelerated Honors Program take Regents courses. Students also enjoy participating in the Performing Arts Talent Program of their choice, including theatrical productions in drama, concerts in chorus, jazz chorus, concert band, jazz band, and participation in the New York State School Music Association competition. Students may also participate in our Visual Arts or Technology/Computer Talent Programs. Parents like how our school promotes a child-centered learning environment. We promote an open door policy where parents can come to our school at any time and speak to a member of our staff. We collaborate with parents and guardians to ensure their child's success at J.H.S 157.

Name: JHS 190 RUSSELL SAGE
overview: Students like our diverse, collaborative school community dedicated to achieving academic excellence for all students. Our nurturing environment fosters a family of lifelong learners. We pride ourselves on delivering challenging and engaging lessons as well as offering a multitude of activities to develop a well-rounded child. We offer Regents courses, Multiple Foreign Language courses, a full talent program which includes fine arts, band, chorus, dance, and drama courses. Students as well as parents appreciate the extra help and support available. We embrace our multicultural student body where we have a 100% respect for 100% of people, 100% of the time philosophy. All students from sixth, seventh, and eighth grade are encouraged to participate in Student Council because it provides them the opportunity to get involved. In addition, students have the opportunity to be inducted into the National Junior Honor Society (NJHS) and participate in the Mathcounts Competition. We have a state-of-the-art science lab, a newly renovated student-friendly library, two computer labs, multiple computer carts, and a brand new fully-furnished dance studio. We have an active Parent Association whose members work tirelessly for the good of our school.

Name: JHS 185 EDWARD BLEEKER
overview: We ensure our students are prepared for college and 21st Century careers. Our teachers provide support and enrichment in an inquiry-based environment. We incorporate STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math) into the curriculum through our Collaborative Learning Program and Software Engineering Pilot. Students experience an interdisciplinary approach to learning through residency programs with Arts Connection, Silk Road Connect, and other cultural partners. Our students participate in engaging field trips, artist visits, and performances, and have won awards in science, math, robotics, art, spelling, and athletic competitions. We partner with Asia Society and Confucius Classrooms to provide our students with cultural experiences, and we offer Chinese language instruction and a dual language program. Parents are integral to our school community and they are invited to participate in activities and take on leadership roles. Daily communication between parents and our school is facilitated via our interactive website and Pupil Path online system.

Giving back to the community is a core belief in our school’s culture. As a result, we have approximately 42 social action projects every year.

Name: JHS 194 WILLIAM CARR
overview: J.H.S. 194 aims to educate children holistically by challenging all students academically, encouraging student voice, and supporting self-expression through a diverse fine and performing arts department, which includes: fine art, concert band, theater, film and media, dance, and photography. J.H.S. 194 strives to support students academically, socially, and emotionally through our grade-level academies, each with a dean, an assistant principal, and two shared guidance counselors. We house a Beacon program on-site which expands the choice of after-school activities for students. Our fine and performing arts department collaborates with numerous arts agencies throughout the city, including: New York City Center, Flushing Town Hall, Jazz from Lincoln Center, Magic Box, and the Leap Program. We have student council in every grade and encourage students to be active members in the planning of school events. We believe parental involvement is essential to student success. We welcome open communication with our families and host a variety of events throughout the year.
